text:
(1) South Street, south side, at the foot of Pike Slip, showing the Manhattan Bridge. June 17, 1936. P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle, at an earlier date. April 15, 1932. P. L. Sperr.

(3) Another view in a northward direction and showing a larger contingent of stationary oyster barges at this point. May 1924. Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.  ASSUMING STREET TO BE EAST AND WEST.

title: Manhattan: South Street - Pike Slip

text:
(1) Pike Slip, east side, north from South Street, to and including Cherry Street. Also shown is Pike Street, (a continuation of Pike Slip, north of Cherry Street,) north from and including Cherry, to and including Division Streets. The view shows on the left, the Manhattan Bridge Anchorage.

July 25, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: Pike Slip - South Street

text:
(1) Pike Slip, east side, north from South Street, to and including Cherry Street. Also shown is Pike Street, (a continuation of Pike Slip, north of Cherry Street,) north from and including Cherry, to and including Division Streets. The view shows on the left, the Manhattan Bridge Anchorage.

July 25, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2) The same, from a different angle.

title: Manhattan: Pike Slip - South Street

text:
South Street, west from (No. 236), but not including Pike Slip, showing prominently (white structure), the Hearst Publications Building extending from Market to Catherine Slips, and (left), the fronts of Piers 31, 30 and 29, East River. Also shown (background), is a portion of the Brooklyn Bridge and (left to right), The Farmer's Loan and Trust Co. Building, the 60 Wall Street Tower (under construction), and the Bank of Manhattan Co. Building.

July 25, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: South Street - Pike Slip

text:
(1)
241, 242 and 243-244 South Street (right), at, adjoining and east of the N.E. corner of Pike Slip. Also shown are Nos. 89 to 79 Peck Slip, east side, north from South to Water Streets. No. 241 (corner house) also bears No. 89 Pike Slip.

July 25, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing only Nos. 241 and 242. Note the farther view on Pike Slip to Cherry Street.

July 25, 1931.

P. L. Sperr.

text:
(1)
241 to 222 South Street, north side, west from, but not including Pike (under the Manhattan Bridge), to, but not including Market Slips. Also shown, is a general view of the surrounding area, as viewed from the Manhattan Bridge.
June 8, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, another view.
June 7, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

title: Manhattan: South Street - Pike Slip

text:
South street (foreground, buildings there upon), north side, east from James Slip (left, not seen in Nos. 1 and 2) to Pike Slip (under the Manhattan Bridge). The prominent structure seen is the plant of the New York Journal and American news paper. To the north of same will rise a large slum clearance project structure known as Knickerbocker Village. This appears in No. 3 in an almost completed form and will shortly be ready for occupancy.

January 8, 1934.
Views 1 and 2
July 31, 1934.

P. L. Sperr,
title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

title: Manhattan: South Street - James Slip

text:
South Street (foreground, north side, west from Rke Slip (right, not seen) to and including Market Slip, as viewed from the Manhattan Bridge. Shown in the midground is Knickerbocker Village under construction. In the background at Foley Square are the Municipal and the Federal Courts Buildings. To the left foreground appears a portion of the New York American Building.

June 26, 1934.

P.L. Sperr
title: Manhattan: South Street - [Between Pike and Market Slips (West).]

text:
251-252 South Street, north side, between Pike and Rutgers Slips, showing a live poultry market (No. 251).

March 19, 1934.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Manhattan: South Street - Pike Slip

text:
South Street, south side, at the foot of Pike Slip, showing oyster barges under the Manhattan Bridge. These floating structures are on the East River waterfront.

April 1, 1937

Berenice Abbott, photo
Federal Art Project
title: Manhattan: South Street - Pike Slip.
